title: 108_hr2061
content: The Act is titled the "National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Reauthorization Act of 2003" and includes general improvements to the national anti-drug media campaign. The Drug-Free Media Campaign Act of 1998 is amended to the National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act, focusing on preventing drug abuse among young people, increasing awareness of adults, and encouraging parental involvement. The National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act aims to prevent drug abuse among young people, increase awareness among adults, and encourage parental discussions about the dangers of drug use. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug Free America, determines the overall purposes and strategy of the national media campaign. The Director is responsible for implementing a national media campaign to prevent drug abuse among young people. They approve the strategy, advertising, and purchase plan. The Partnership for a Drug-Free America is also involved in the campaign. The Director is responsible for implementing a national media campaign to prevent drug abuse among young people. The Partnership for a Drug-Free America is involved in recommending strategies and creating advertising for the campaign. The Director implements a national media campaign to prevent drug abuse among young people. Advertisements are tested before national media use to ensure effectiveness and meet industry standards. A media buying contractor is hired to plan and purchase advertising time and space for the campaign. A cap of $5,000,000 per fiscal year is set for developing advertising material. SEC. 104. FINANCIAL AND PERFORMANCE ACCOUNTABILITY. The Director is required to conduct audits and examinations of records as specified in the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act. An independent entity must evaluate the effectiveness of the national media campaign annually using data from various studies and publications. The Director must evaluate the national media campaign annually using data from studies like the Attitude Tracking Study and the National Household Survey on Drug Abuse. Relevant studies determined by the Director must also be included in the evaluation report submitted to Congress. The Director must submit an annual report to Congress detailing the national media campaign's strategy, objectives, efficiency, advertising plans, responsible fund usage, and contracts with external entities. Authorization of $195,000,000 for the Office of National Drug Control Policy for fiscal years 2004 through 2008.
